YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

Debate on the Address
(Third Day)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question [17th July, 1959],

    That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly." '-(The Deputy Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.34 p.m.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, concerning the debate which relates to Government's policy which is contained in the speech made by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara of Singapore, I would like to continue what I have explained

Column: 230

in this Assembly. I wish to comment on the P.A.P. stand in connection with Home Affairs. It reads as follows:

    "In the past the Police Force has been regarded as an instrument of Colonial rulers and as a thing apart from the people.

    With the attainment of internal self-government there is a significant change in the role of the Police. It will no longer be an instrument to further the aims of a Colonial regime. In a self-governing country the role of the police will be to protect the life and property of the people, to maintain peace and order and to protect the people's elected Government from being undermined and subverted from within and without. It is a primary duty of this Government to establish mutual confidence and respect between the people and the police."

    Mr Speaker, in connection with the section which I have just read out, it is my opinion that this matter is not appropriate to be included in the Government's policy today. I am of the opinion that it is incorrect to regard the police as an instrument of Colonial rulers. We must know that the police is an instrument of the State which has protected the peace of the country until today. Therefore, Mr Speaker, in my opinion, the police is not an instrument of Colonial rulers but is an instrument of a service whose staff are loyal to the rules and regulations as framed by the Government in power at that time. I would like to say that the Singapore police has served conscientiously and this can be proved. To say that the police is an instrument of Colonial rulers is nonsensical and truly misleading. The services of the police in Singapore have been made at great sacrifice as can be seen in the history of Singapore from the time that it inculcated the spirit of anti-Colonialism until today. If the Singapore police is considered an instrument or a thing apart from the people, and not fulfilling its duties, then I am sure that Singapore will not be what it is today. Who has been responsible for bringing about the peace which has resulted in Singapore being what it is today? The Singapore police has taken an active part in clearing Singapore of Communist subversion, whether from within or without. Therefore, Mr Speaker, I cannot agree that the Singapore police is an instrument of Colonial rule. If the Singapore police was

Column: 231

so and carried out the wishes of the Colonial rulers then we could not even smell the Assembly which is in session today. And certainly the general elections, whether by compulsory voting or otherwise, will not be for the people of Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, the merchants here must surely be perturbed and worried because their property will not be protected if our police force is inefficient in rendering its services. But, Mr Speaker, there are certain groups who regard the police as having rendered many good services. For instance, by ending the riots and helping to combat fires and floods and maintaining the peace and stability of our country. Therefore, I hope that the services of the Singapore police will continue as before, according to the change of time.

    Now, Mr Speaker, I would like to make a number of points based on the special position of the indigenous people of Singapore. We know that the present Government was elected by the people according to its manifesto or platform, which has resulted in their winning an overwhelming victory. But in the programme supported by the Government, there is no positive mention of the special position of the Malays, which is contained in the preamble o the constitution and which has been agreed to and recognised by all the parties represented in the previous Government. What is the Government's intention then? To receive graduates from Malay schools in the Government service in its effort to make Malay the national language? Can these Malay graduates be given an assurance that they will be received into the Government services? Because we know that their standard of education is not at par with those graduates who pass out from schools other than Malay schools. This is one instance where we want an assurance from the Government - whether graduates from the Malay schools will be received as clerks in the Government service and whether, if they become members of certain political parties, they will be accepted to serve in the Government services where they think fit.

Column: 232



    If we consider the position today, Mr Speaker, the qualifications of Malay students who pass out from Malay schools will need another language in which they must be fluent, and that is the English language. Then only can the pupils from the Malay schools be accepted as interpreters or translators of English into Malay and from Malay into English.

    Before I move my amendment, these are the few points, Mr Speaker, which I think are essential and important in relation to the special position of the Malays who wish to stand on an equal footing with their brothers who live in Singapore today. Apart from that, Mr Speaker, perhaps there are among them some who are lucky enough to be able to be accepted as probationary teachers to teach in Malay schools. But with the existing policy to make Malay the national language and preparations to get Malay children to work hand in hand with their brothers, I fear that, when Malay has become the sole national language and is spoken fluently by our non-Malay brothers, the job of the Malay teachers will be endangered, because there are perhaps teachers from English or other schools who are efficient in all respects and fluent in the Malay language and they can teach in Malay schools instead. Here then is the fear of the Malay people, particularly the U.M.N.O., which I represent. What we want is a positive assurance that Malay children will be given the chance to work with their brothers. Under the circumstances, Mr Speaker, Sir, where is the special position of the Malays who have been recognised by all the Parties represented in the previous Government under the Rendel Constitution as the indigenous people in Singapore? This provision is contained in the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council. There is no doubt about it, but what is in doubt - and I would like an assurance from the Government side on this - is whether it is contained in the speech made by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. Although the People's Action Party has won 43 seats with 54 per cent of the electorate voting

Column: 233

for them as a result of compulsory voting, and they have formed a Government, this is our fear because, in principle, there is no mention of the special position of the Malays as is contained in the Singapore Constitution. Mr Speaker, Sir, the phraseology in the Singapore Constitution can be said to be in legal terms, and it has become a cause of concern as to whether this policy can be implemented or not, and this is one of the things which we expect the Government to declare sincerely so that we can ascertain how the Malay children of Singapore in the future can find their means of livelihood, because, as I have said just now, they have to compete with their brothers. Why I say that, Mr Speaker, is because the constitution that we have today is different from that in the Federation of Malaya. However, not only the Government but also the Opposition want reunion with the Federation, and I believe this is one of the reasons which can save the one and a half million people of Singapore from the difficulties which we are bound to face, because Singapore has no natural resources and it depends only on entrepot trade. Therefore, Mr Speaker, we want to reunite with the Federation. I say that that is the only way which can save the population of Singapore.

    It is essential that I state that what we are concerned with is to free ourselves from the bondage of colonialism since 1819, when Sir Stamford Raffles sailed into Singapore with his boats to find only 20 huts in Singapore. During the space of 140 years, from the time when Singapore fell into the hands of the East India Company, the Malays have experienced innumerable difficulties and hardships from colonial administration, which depended on the self-respect of the Malays and the exchange of culture between one race and another. From that year until 1959, Mr Speaker, about 140 years, the Malays have experienced considerable hardships in all spheres of life. With that on our conscience and the principles which our ancestors have passed on to us and which

Column: 234

we have supported for years, now is the opportunity for us to ask the Parties concerned - where, in the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech, is there mention about the position of the Malays, as contained in the Singapore Constitution? It is not only the request of my own organisation, U.M.N.O., that it be answered, but it is also supported by all political organisations represented in this Assembly based on the Rendel Constitution. I wish to emphasise that it will be accepted by the United Kingdom through the Colonial Office. I hope that it will be implemented in peace and harmony and that it could be included in the speech. I am not speaking today to demand justice or special position for the Malays but to request the Government to answer why it had not been mentioned in the policy speech, as it had been agreed to, in the past, by the previous Government. Therefore, Mr Speaker, concerning the Malays who are desirous of prosperity for this country through proper channels, we want it to be emphatically included in the policy speech, as I have said just now, because the phraseology contained in the Singapore Constitution can be said to be in legal terms and can therefore be confusing. Thus, we desire to go forward on the same footing in all things.

    Now let us see what took place during the last 140 years. The Malay children have been colonialised. If we resisted, force would be used, or the leaders would be bribed. The Malays have shown that they are lovers of peace. We wish to move forward together; we do not wish to be left behind. Rather we would like to work together so that it can be said in this Assembly and to the people at large that the Malays are desirous of prosperity for this country through proper channels.

    Mr Speaker, the methods and approach that should be used to bring this about should be based on mutual understanding. We have been disappointed in many matters, apart from those which I have already mentioned. I dare say these disappointments have not been caused by the Malays but by others. No opportunity whatsoever has been given to the

Column: 235

Malays, whether in the political or economic field. How many firms or business houses in Singapore are financed by Malays? If they say that the Malays have no initiative, we will show them that we have the ability and we have the willingness to work in all fields. The backwardness of the Malays is a very severe blow to us. It is this oppression which has resulted in the Malay people being made fools of in past years; but the time has come when we are aware and we want to demand that we be given an opportunity to work in those fields. We know that previously in Kampong Glam and Kampong Kaji there were many Malays who traded there. It could be said that it was a town for the Malays where they could trade. But with no attention from the Government, the Malays were let down. Now is the time for us to seek the same opportunities and the same treatment in all fields. With oppression, with no opportunity for trading given to the Malays, refusal to give aid to certain bodies, the matters which I have said just now have become the monopoly of capitalists and the Malays could only become consumers, because they have no means whatsoever of conducting business. Therefore the Malays have been compelled to become wage-earners in order to get jobs which require ability - from one oppression to another until today, if we carefully study the position in all spheres of life, the Malays are very much lacking in prominent men. If there are prominent men in the Government, it cannot be said that they have come from a certain class. Mr Speaker, as I quoted just now from the Utusan Melayu, the previous coalition Government was in a position to establish the Malay Chamber of Commerce although its functions were not clear. Often such bodies appealed to the proper authorities in writing to ask whether it was right to refuse or to give help. So, let it be known today, or at any future time, what are the matters I have raised so that the Malays will know once and for all. The Utusan Melayu of today mentioned the interview of the Chairman of the Malay Chamber of Commerce, Inche Alwi, with the Government. The Government stated that it will help the Chamber to the tune of $13-million to

Column: 236

help the Malays economically. This, of course, is of moment to us, but the speech by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara contained nothing about the matter.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there are many other matters which Government should clarify, I must admit that my questions are not based on communal feelings, but the Malays want to protect their culture - live in the kampongs, have a little garden to grow vegetables during their leisure and breed poultry. Therefore, because of the demand of the lower-income groups, the previous Government set up Malay settlements. It also set aside money for the building of low-cost houses for Malays in these settlements. Is it the intention of the present Government, whose policy is for a democratic, non-Communist, Socialist Singapore or Malaya, to continue expanding the Malay settlements in Singapore?

    As I said, the Malays cannot adapt themselves to living in multi-storeyed houses or flats, which are foreign to them. They do not like it. They feel more comfortable in kampongs. This is not because they are communal, but because they want to live in peace and harmony with their fellowmen. This is not uncommon with the Malays not only in Singapore, but also in the Federation. We merely ask for expansion of Malay settlements in line with what the previous Government had done in voting $340,000 for the erection of low-cost houses. This is one of the aspects of the special position of the Malays.

    It is appropriate that the main policy of the Government is to re-unite with the Federation, but the policy of the Federation of Malaya Government today is not identical. Malay reservations are different altogether from Malay settlements. We do not ask for Malay reservations. We ask for land to live on, land owned by the Government, land which remains the property of the Government no matter which Party is in power. This is a point which the Government must consider carefully - the difference between Malay reservations in the Federation and the special position of the Malays in Singapore. The Federation of Malaya has

Column: 237

achieved independence and its Constitution provides for Malay reservations. Here, we do not demand such things; we merely wish to clarify in principle the special position of the Malays.

    Apart from Malay settlements, Mr Speaker, Sir, and help to the Malays to solve their problem of building low-cost houses in these settlements, is the Government making provision for promoting the position of the Malays? Has promotion for Malays in Government service today any connection with the special position of the Malays? In my opinion and that of the organization I represent, this also concerns the special position of the Malays. The Malays who are still serving in Government departments are not given any assurance in the matter of promotion in line with the special position of the Malays. There are no special channels to enable the Malays to hold high positions. Does promotion in their jobs not come within the special position of the indigenous Malays? If Government policy provides for promotion of Malays under their special position mentioned in the Constitution, I am sure that within the next few months the Malays will be benefited.

    Mr Speaker, this is one of the big issues. We know that there are many Malays in Government service, there is no necessity for me to mention the number in the various departments. There may not be any opportunity for them to reach high positions in the civil service or in other services.

    If knowledge in the true sense of the Malay language is a condition for promotion, I believe my organisation will accept that there is a special position of the Malays. But there are many administrative hurdles in Government which preclude Malays from being accorded their special position. It is not proper to say that promotion in jobs has no relation with the special position of the Malays, and I very much regret to say that the hopes of the Malays are very limited indeed. However, if Government had emphasised that special position includes promotion in jobs. I am quite sure the Malays will be assured.

Column: 238



    Mr Speaker, on the administration policy of the Government, I would like to stress that we of the Opposition, particularly U.M.N.O., consider that Government can help its citizens in the field of employment. Is it the policy of Government to have a quota system for Malays to enter Government service? Or will Government require commercial houses to employ Malays?

    We know that apart from the capitalists who come from abroad, there are also capitalists who are citizens of this country and have invested money here. We find many of them do not want Malays as employees in their firms or businesses. Here, therefore, is one example of oppression.

    Another serious question is that of the future livelihood of Malay children.

    We do not like communalism, and the time has come when we must abolish it completely. Government should introduce legislation so that it will become obligatory for foreign-owned or locally-owned enterprises to take in Malays as part of their employees, so that the Malays will have an opportunity to mix with the other sections of the population. Today, we see that the bus companies are not prepared to accept Malays as drivers or conductors, let alone as inspectors. There are also many business houses and factories which are not prepared to employ and train Malays in work apart, I dare say, from work as messengers, peons or gardeners in their big mansions.

    The time has come when the Government must introduce legislation not based on communalism, but on the one objective we are aiming for, namely, to bury colonialism which has oppressed us, and march forward towards independence, shaping and colouring it the way we like. We are responsible for this.

    Mr Speaker, the time has come when we must be united and mutually implement what is set out in the Constitution so that the Malays will not have the fears I have expressed, with regard to their special position. If we want to bury the colonialism which we hate, we must remember that the U.M.N.O. has opposed compulsory voting 100 per cent

Column: 239

and vehemently. However, in accordance with the Constitution and in a spirit of compromise, we accepted the majority decision and abided by it. But having compromised, we hope that the emphasis on the special position of the Malays will be guaranteed by Government.

    We do not like compulsory voting. We opposed it vehemently. But because we accepted the principle of government by the majority, we were prepared to compromise and work in peace and harmony with others with a view to formulating one objective and one nation. Our population is ever increasing. Therefore we are afraid that through compulsory voting, we will be swamped by others although my organisation, the U.M.N.O., has opposed it strongly. If despite our spirit of compromise our position is not going to be guaranteed we are afraid, from an understanding of political parties today, that the special position of the Malays will be taken away completely.

    We are still concerned with the attainment of independence for Singapore. We would like the Government to prove its sincerity concerning the special position of the Malays. If the Government can prove positively that it has no sinister motive, we will uphold and appreciate that and, at the same time, will work together so that the Constitution will be a success.

Column: 239

Column: 240

YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

(Debate on the Address)
Debate resumed.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, to continue my speech, I have emphasised the special position of the Malays which is not mentioned in the speech on Government policy made by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. I would like to stress that we will work together. We do not wish to violate the Constitution before the present five-year term. We are not withdrawing from the way towards attaining full independence. Therefore, Mr Speaker, the special position of the Malays must be emphasised to the Malays in particular so that U.M.N.O. in Singapore can know whether Government accepts it or otherwise and whether to negotiate to bury the present Constitution before its term of four or five years, and so that Members can carry out their responsibilities.

    This is the moment for the Government to emphasise the special position of the Malays. We the Malays in Singapore want to change the new Constitution to a better one. We do not wish to live under any kind of colonialism which may taste sweet but is at the same time dangerous.

    Therefore, Mr Speaker, we will abolish the present Constitution and work towards that aim. The Government policy statement says that Singapore should re-unite with and become a unit of the Federation of Malaya which is already independent. The special position of the Malays is in such matters including educational, religious, economic, social and cultural, and in the Malay language. It is the responsibility of the Government to encourage, foster and promote the special position of the Malays in all these matters before we re-unite with the Federation which, as I have said, has a different system of Government in that it has Islam as the state religion, Malay reservations and so on.

    Sir, the Singapore Government must particularly emphasise to the Malays

Column: 241

their position so that they will be satisfied that the present Government will foster their political, social, religious, economic and cultural conditions and the Malay language. This is the main task and I want to ask the Government how it can carry it out. If the Government is unable to stress the special position of the Malays in its policy statement, then it is the responsibility of the representatives of U.M.N.O. to bring home to the Government this matter which is of paramount importance. Before we begin a new system of Government there are many matters which we must remember, such as that the Malays must be sincerely assured about what their special position will be.

    The Government today has a responsibility, as I have explained, towards Malay graduates. When the P.A.P. got into the City Council, its policy was to accept into the staff Malay students who had passed Standard VII in Malay Schools. Is the P.A.P. Government today implementing that policy? Too many of our citizens are unemployed, one cause being that the War Department still employs people who are not citizens of Singapore. Will the Government take action and provide for our unemployed citizens jobs in the Government from the taxes collected from the citizens themselves?

    This has also become a question mark. The Government can carry this out - that in the years ahead Malays with Malay language qualifications can find employment in certain places instead of only holding the lowest posts in Government. Therefore, I hope that it will be the policy of this Government, as of the past City Council, to accept Malay graduates who have passed Standard VII in Malay Schools into Government service. This is a responsibility of the Government - the provision of opportunities for Malays in accordance with their special right. And in such provision which concerns the fate or destiny of the Malays, we will offer healthy criticism.

    On the matter of religion. Islam is the religion of all the Malays; they do not follow any other. Therefore, Mr Speaker, what will the Government do

Column: 242

to protect the religion of the Malays in accordance with their special position? Will the Government restrict the propagation of our holy religion which is supported by all Malays, not only in Singapore but also in the Federation? Will it give positive help to mosques, schools and other places of worship? Any kind of help, material or otherwise, is very important. This matter is a responsibility of the Government. If we go to the kampongs and visit the suraus, the mosques and the public schools in them, we will see that these places of worship are very backward, so to speak. They are not proper buildings. They are the results of colonialist oppression, all forms - positive and negative. This matter is also a responsibility of the Government because it relates to the special position of the Malays mentioned in the Constitution. I am sure Government help and special treatment will be given to these mosques and schools in the kampongs, which are already receiving help from the kampong folk themselves. Because of what they have experienced in the past many years I will emphasise again that it is the responsibility of Government to provide for them now, in accordance with the Constitution. We must demand that Government pay serious attention to spreading the teachings of Islam, especially among the Malay children.

    Sir, Government must give help and assistance so that, in turn, it can fulfil its duties. The Malays have specific desires, needs and aspirations and that is why U.M.N.O., particularly in Singapore, has pioneered the struggle. In the past, we were poor, backward and lacking in ability, admittedly in all fields. Now we have a clear assurance regarding the rights and the special position of the Malays in Singapore, who are recognised as the indigenous people. Mr Speaker, Sir, I am of the opinion that these are important points for the betterment and advancement of the Malays in Singapore, who are most in need of advancement and tranquility in all spheres.

    Once again, I repeat that I hope Government will discharge its duty in regard to the special position of the Malays; that not only will it fight for

Column: 243

the Malay language to be the national language, but also initiate and implement programmes based on the provisions contained in the Constitution of our self-governing Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, another of the many things which this Assembly must consider carefully before I move my amendment and retire to listen to the Government side is the matter of culture. It can be said that Singapore is situated in the heart of the Malay Archipelago - it is surrounded by the Federation of Malaya, the Republic of Indonesia with its thousands of islands, British North Borneo, Brunei and Sarawak, and the Philippines which can be considered as part of the Malay Archipelago. As such, the culture of Singapore must, in my opinion, be based on Malay culture if we are going to establish a Malayan culture. Is it the Government's intention to establish a Malayan culture? We know our position and we hope that the Government will stress this matter of Malayan culture. It will not be difficult for my organisation, U.M.N.O., to consider and accept a culture which is Malayan.

    In the Federation today the national identity has not yet been established. We want to hear from the non-Malays what kind of national identity they wish to have. The time will come when the Federation of Malaya will choose its national identity, one supported by and agreed to by the whole population comprising many communities. The situation is the same concerning culture in Singapore. I say this because what struck me most recently when the P.A.P. gained its overwhelming victory and introduced its successful election candidates at the City Hall, was the use of symbols. I am at a loss to understand why. If we were to visit that building now we can see that all the symbols are unintelligible to the Malays. This is a source of concern and fear to the Malays. This is a serious matter requiring Government's attention in our progress towards establishing a national identity for all sections of a community with undivided loyalty towards Singapore's independence.

    Therefore, Mr Speaker, because of such fears and because of the omission

Column: 244

of any mention in the speech made by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara of the main issues in relation to the special position of the Malays in Singapore, I regret to have to move an amendment to the motion moved by the Deputy Prime Minister as follows-

    "at end, to add-

    but regret that the speech did not in principle clarify the special position of the Malays who are recognised as the indigenous people of the Island of Singapore'."

    That, Mr Speaker, is my amendment to the motion made by the Deputy Prime Minister in this Assembly a few days back. I have given the reasons regarding the several main issues concerning the special position of the Malays in Singapore. That is all I can do to stress and bring home to the public the doubts which have led to the moving of my amendment. I think this is important to the advancement of the special position of the Malays so that they will move forward with their fellow citizens in the next five years of the Government's life and further, struggle with them to free not only ourselves but our State from colonialism which is not only disliked by us, but is also condemned by the world at large.

    That is all Mr Speaker, Sir, on the amendment which I move today.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib (Southern Islands): I second the amendment.

    Mr Speaker: The hon. Member for the Southern Islands has already spoken to the main Question and therefore he cannot second the amendment.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to second the amendment without prejudice to speak later on.
